title: Organisers threaten to BAN runner if he continues to push three-year-old around 10k course in PRAM
text:
A runner could be banned from future events if he continues to push his daughter around in races in a pram.

Dez O'Connor, 35, from Plymouth, Devon, likes to run in charity races and for the last three years has been taking his daughter Elsie, three, with him in a specially designed pushchair.

But he has now been left seething by a letter from the organisers of a charity 10K run, Britain's Ocean City Running Series, raising safety concerns.

In the letter, they said that although no action would be taken for his previous races, he would be banned if he tried to compete with the pram again.

The letter said Dez was in breach of rules and a safety hazard to other runners and Elsie.

Dez O'Connor, 35, from Plymouth, Devon, likes to run in charity races with his daughter Elsie in a pram

Hundreds of people have signed a petition supporting Dez and calling for the ban to be reversed.

Dez, a firefighter and scaffolder, said: 'They said it was against the rules of UK Athletics, but we spoke to them and they said there was no rule and it was down to organiser discretion.

'I asked what the risk was but they wouldn't tell me, they wouldn't let me look at the risk assessment. I asked if we could put in control measures but they just ignored me.

'They said it was against the rules and that's all they would say on the matter.'

Because of the letter, Dez decided not to run in the Plymouth 10K over the weekend but took part in a training run the day before.

He added: 'I have run the half marathon with Elsie three times. After I did the last half I got an email saying if I ran with the pram again I would be banned.

'If they're worried about space I'll start from the back, I've been doing this for years and most people are very receptive.'

Britain's Ocean City Running Series have now threatened to ban him if he does it again

Dez said that he started running with his daughter so that he could spend time with his wife, Becky, when she started running.

But now it's one of Elsie's favourite hobbies and she always asks to go for a run.

Dez added: 'It started because my wife wanted to run and I wanted to join her, so we put the little one in the pram.

'She loves it and likes going to the races, she likes hearing the people cheer and getting a medal at the end.

'I don't see the problem with it, it doesn't make any sense to me.'

The organisers say they have a legal responsibility to 'protect children' and that running with a pram is not allowed.

The letter reads: 'We have recently been reported that you used a buggy at the Half Marathon, I understand it is a runners one and specially built to accommodate running long distances with your child however this is against UK Athletics rules and regulations.

'I have gone back and checked, I saw that you did ask permission on 8 January 2017 and that you have done it previous years as I assume you had no reply from my predecessor at the time.

'As you did ask permission and you were never informed otherwise when you should have been in previous years we will not ban you from future events, however we insist that you please do not use the buggy again.

'If it is used in any future events, we will have to remove your results and not allow you to run again in any future events.'
